paragraphs.text: Privatising Mexico's oil industry spells disaster.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Considering Mexico's history and the present political context, it's no surprise that the majority of the Mexican population nowadays is either deeply suspicious of President Pena Nieto or just opposed to the current fast-track drive to privatise oil and pass it into the hands of foreign oligopolies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: At present, Mexico suffers from an extremely weak state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where the vast majority of crimes go unaddressed because of a judicial vacuum
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: More than 22,000 forced disappearances have occurred since 2007 and more than 70,000 people have been killed since 2006
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Almost every week we hear about more mass graves discovered
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most recently, a massacre of students in Iguala shook the nation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Mexico also suffers from the third largest illicit economy in the world, according to the Global Financial Integrity Report
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Clearly, organised crime is openly challenging and fragmenting the state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the face of these facts even President Nieto has admitted in public speeches that Mexico's legal system is in shambles
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: International experience and basic common sense indicate that a country must possess a minimum standard of the rule of law in order to be able to foster social benefits for most of its population when privatising state assets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Without functional regulatory and judicial controls, it is technically and politically not feasible for any oil-funded social development fund to effectively spread wealth to future generations through new public education programmes, a modernised public health, adequate environmental standards and a much-improved physical infrastructure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Absolutely nothing today indicates that Mexico can implement privatisation of the oil infrastructure at even the most basic standards of security, transparency, effectiveness and efficiency
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a Mexican paradox occurs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: insecurity still runs at record highs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: foreign money keeps pouring in
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's going on?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Since the beginning of the still unfinished democratic transition and since the economic opening to international trade of the early 1990s, Mexico managed to attract billions of dollars per year in foreign direct investment
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: most of this money has been channelled into politically managed non-competitive sectors in the hands of Mexican "state courtesans" disguised as private entrepreneurs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who over the last 25 years created vast oligopolies out of the privatisation of state assets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The privatisation process in Mexico has largely been conducted through dubious procedures orchestrated by corrupt federal governments
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All this happened in the midst of a Mexican economy lacking technological innovation with low productivity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: where more than half of what is produced and consumed is exchanged within informal/illicit markets
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Nevertheless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: these so-called private oligopolies within the mining, banking and telecommunications industries operate in a crony capitalistic fashion by attracting foreign investors to politically protected markets in which governments (through bribes and subsidies) ensure rates of return two to five times above the international average
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How can, for example, German or US oligopolies presently investing in Mexico fail to fall in love with such a "generous" corrupt system?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The forthcoming Mexican oil privatisation falls comfortably within this "legally corrupt" economic framework
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: harsh social realities have a way of trumping politics most of the time
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Mexican writer and journalist Ana Lilia Perez published in 2012 a book titled"The Black Cartel"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: in which she provides a description of massive organised crime infiltration within the top managerial echelons of the state-run oil company, PEMEX
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The nature of the organised crime infiltration covers technical and political appointees at PEMEX
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Moreover
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: with thorough documentation, Ms Perez provides a detailed account of how and where a large portion of the oil extracted and distributed by PEMEX is currently stolen through illegal operations
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: These have been linked to Mexican politicians and US and Mexican private companies selling illegal Mexican oil to the markets in Canada, Mexico and the US, with the complicity of the Mexican armed forces supposedly responsible for protecting the PEMEX infrastructure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The current illegal oil trafficking comes with high-level political corruption, intense armed conflict causing thousands of deaths per month and frequent acts of terrorism against the PEMEX infrastructure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One cannot expect this armed conflict scenario to just go away after privatisation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In this kind of context, any honest foreign investor bidding within a Mexican oil privatisation process should have his or her head checked or otherwise possess enough political clout within Mexico or the financial capacity to bribe with millions of dollars the government ladder and pay for a vast praetorian guard of security personnel to manage the armed chaos ahead
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In comparison
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: dealing with other oil producing countries with problematic states, such as Nigeria, would seem like a walk in the park
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Shareholders of oil companies can only expect low economic returns and chaos from investing in the Mexican oil sector
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: unless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: prior to any private investment drive, an international judicial cooperation effort starts dismantling the vast organised crime networks within the Mexican oil business and beyond
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This international judicial cooperation must entail the actual implementation of a serious anti-corruption programme within the Mexican state with much broader conflict of interest and traffic of influence statutes, all monitored by reputable international civil society organisations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Furthermore
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the failure of the Mexican state needs to be corrected with the installation of autonomous investigative units for economic crimes within each Mexican region and the creation of witness protection programmes for cases of political corruption linked to organised crime
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: These reforms will be good for Mexican society in general and also good for the pockets of Mexican and foreign oil investors
paragraphs.label: assumption
